Internal environment:
- *Restricting factors* (−): Moderate–low political stability, high government stability (before 2011), many years in office (before 2011), unsuccessful opposition
- *Enabling factors* (+): Low government stability (after 2011), short time in office (after 2011), frequent elections
External environment:
- (−) High–moderate regional stability (before 2011), few coups in region (before 2011), many violent protests in region (after 2011), few nonviolent protests in region (before 2011)
- (+) Low regional stability (after 2011), coups in region (after 2011), few violent protests in region (before 2011), many nonviolent protests in region (after 2011)
Reputational environment: - High levels of state-based shaming, especially after 2005

Internal environment:
- (−) High–moderate government stability, no elections, unsuccessful/nonexistent opposition
- (+) High political stability, few years in office
External environment:
- (−) High–moderate regional stability, few violent protests in region
- (+) Coups in region, few nonviolent protests in region
Reputational environment: - High levels of state-based shaming, especially after 2005

Internal environment:
- (−) Moderate–low political stability (very low in 2000), high government stability, many de facto years in office (because of Putin's shadow presidency during Medvedev's term)
- (+) Frequent elections, successful opposition
External environment:
- (−) High regional stability, few nonviolent protests in region
- (+) Coups in region (especially in 1990s), few violent protests in region
Reputational environment: - Low levels of state-based shaming (with peaks in 2008 and 2014)
